entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 5:24AM CDT by NWS Quad Cities IA IL
entry.summary:
Southwest winds today will gust to 25 to 30 mph through early to mid afternoon. These winds, along with unseasonably warm temperatures and low humidity, will result in a high fire danger today. Any fires that develop will spread quickly.
Avoid brush or grass burning today, use extra caution with farm and outdoor equipment, and do not carelessly discard cigarettes.

entry.title: High Wind Watch issued March 12 at 3:20AM PDT until March 14 at 1:00PM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Northeast winds 30 to 40 mph with possible gusts up to 65 mph.
* WHERE...Santa Clarita Valley, Central Ventura County Valleys, Western Santa Monica Mountains Recreational Area, Calabasas and Agoura Hills, Southeastern Ventura County Valleys, Santa Susana Mountains, Southern Ventura County Mountains, Interstate 5 Corridor, Western San Gabriel Mountains and Highway 14 Corridor and Eastern San Gabriel Mountains.
* WHEN...From late Wednesday night through Thursday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Damaging winds could blow down large objects such as trees and power lines. Power outages are possible. Travel could be difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...There is some uncertaity on the exact locations of the strongest winds and it is likely that not all of this area will see warning level winds. But all people in the watch area should stay abreast of the lastest developments in this wind event.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 4:17AM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
Mountain snow and lower elevation rain showers will spread across western and northern NM Wednesday, creating slick travel above 8,000 feet. Conditions deteriorate Thursday and Friday as a strong backdoor cold front surges down the eastern plains and funnels through the gaps of the central mountain chain. This will drop snow levels down to near valley floors and create damaging wind gusts up to 70 mph in east Albuquerque near the base of Tijeras Canyon. Gusty east winds combined with moderate to locally heavy snowfall rates could also create blizzard-like conditions along I-40 through Tijeras Canyon and over the Continental Divide along US-550 and I-40. Significant snowfall accumulations and patchy blowing snow will create hazardous travel conditions elsewhere in the high terrain of western and northern New Mexico Thursday and Friday, particularly over mountain passes. Slick travel may linger into the weekend and early next week, although confidence is lower given the high storm track uncertainty. Travelers should closely monitor the forecast for updates in the coming days.
Monitor NOAA weather radio, weather.gov/abq or your local media for the latest weather updates. You may also monitor road conditions online at nmroads.com, via telephone at 1-800-432-4269, or by dialing 5-1-1 in New Mexico.

entry.title: Wind Chill Advisory issued March 12 at 1:57AM AKDT until March 14 at 1:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills to 55 below zero. North winds 15 to 30 mph. Areas of blowing snow with reduced visibility.
* WHERE...The West Coast of Alaska north of the Yukon Delta.
* WHEN...Until 1 PM AKDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...North winds of 15 to 30 mph will continue along the the West Coast of Alaska through Thursday. The strongest winds, coldest wind chills, and lowest visibility in blowing snow are occuring through areas channeled from the north such as at Shaktoolik, Johnson's Camp (between White Mountain and Safety), Deering, and the Bering Strait. The wind chills becoming less severe during the afternoon each day. Winds are expected to decrease late on Thursday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Noatak Valley; Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Baldwin Peninsula; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 5:52AM EDT by NWS Marquette MI
entry.summary:
Gusty west to northwest winds as high 15 to 20 mph this afternoon, combined with dry and warm conditions and a lack of recent rainfall will lead to elevated wildfire potential today across the interior west half of Upper Michigan.
Avoid any outdoor burning today. Immediately report any wildfires to local emergency services by calling 911.
Burn restrictions remain in effect. For complete details, visit www.dnr.state.mi.us/burnpermits, or by calling 866-922-2876.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ontonagon; Baraga; Marquette; Gogebic; Iron; Dickinson; Menominee; Southern Houghton

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 12 at 2:47AM PDT until March 12 at 11:32PM PDT by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Seattle WA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Washington...
Skokomish River At Potlatch affecting Mason County.
.The Skokomish River will continue to rise into this morning, cresting later this morning, due to heavy rainfall since yesterday across the southern Olympics.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Skokomish River at Potlatch.
* WHEN...Until late this evening.
* IMPACTS...At 16.5 feet, the Skokomish River will cause widespread flooding of pasture lands, with water flowing quickly over West Bourgault Road and Skokomish Valley Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:30 AM PDT Tuesday the stage was 16.2 feet. - Flood stage is 16.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early this morning to a crest of 16.9 feet late this morning. It will then fall below flood stage this afternoon. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 16.8 feet on 11/23/1990. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Mason, WA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE THIS EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 3:34AM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
Mountain snow and lower elevation rain showers will spread across western and northern NM Wednesday, creating slick travel above 8,000 feet. Conditions deteriorate Thursday and Friday as a strong backdoor cold front surges down the eastern plains and funnels through the gaps of the central mountain chain. This will drop snow levels down to near valley floors and create damaging wind gusts up to 70 mph in east Albuquerque near the base of Tijeras Canyon. Gusty east winds combined with moderate to locally heavy snowfall rates could also create blizzard-like conditions along I-40 through Tijeras Canyon and over the Continental Divide along US-550 and I-40. Significant snowfall accumulations and patchy blowing snow will create hazardous travel conditions elsewhere in the high terrain of western and northern New Mexico Thursday and Friday, particularly over mountain passes. Slick travel may linger into the weekend and early next week, although confidence is lower given the high storm track uncertainty. Travelers should closely monitor the forecast for updates in the coming days.
Monitor NOAA weather radio, weather.gov/abq or your local media for the latest weather updates. You may also monitor road conditions online at nmroads.com, via telephone at 1-800-432-4269, or by dialing 5-1-1 in New Mexico.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 3:46AM CDT by NWS Hastings NE
entry.summary:
Although a formal Warning for fire weather is not currently in effect this afternoon due to forecast parameters expected to fall slightly short of Warning issuance criteria, solidly near- critical conditions are likely in most of this area mainly between 1 and 6 PM. This will be due to the combination of north- northwest winds gusting at least 20 MPH, and relative humidity as low as 15 to 25 percent.
Up to a few hours of critical fire weather conditions cannot be ruled out, especially in Rooks County Kansas, where wind gusts over 25 MPH would be most favored.
Despite the absence of any formal Warnings at this time, caution is certainly advised this afternoon if engaging in any activities that could possibly spark a wildfire.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Phillips; Smith; Jewell; Rooks; Osborne; Mitchell; Furnas; Harlan; Franklin; Webster

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 3:37AM CDT by NWS Green Bay WI
entry.summary:
Recent dry conditions, warming temperatures, increasing southwest to west winds and low relative humidity will result in elevated fire weather conditions across north-central, northeast and central Wisconsin this afternoon. The main concern will be in grassy areas.
Persons are urged to be careful with any activities that could potentially lead to a wildland fire. Campfires, outdoor grills, smoking materials, chain saws, and all-terrain vehicles all have the potential to throw a spark and ignite a wildfire.
Debris burning is the number one cause of wildfires in Wisconsin. Contact the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources to check on any burning restrictions that may be in place in your area.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Vilas; Oneida; Forest; Florence; Northern Marinette County; Lincoln; Langlade; Menominee; Northern Oconto County; Marathon; Shawano; Wood; Portage; Waupaca; Waushara; Southern Marinette County; Southern Oconto County

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 3:37AM CDT by NWS Milwaukee/Sullivan WI
entry.summary: Elevated fire weather conditions are expected today due to breezy southwest winds and low relative humidities in the 20-30% range, with potential for them to drop even further if temperatures get a bit higher than expected. This is primarily for areas north and west of a line from Madison to Fond du Lac, though Sheboygan will be breezy enough to have some higher concerns as well. Outdoor fires will have potential to quickly spread in these conditions and any burning should be done with extreme caution.

* 20 FOOT WINDS...West 25 to 35 mph with gusts near 50 mph.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 2:42AM CDT by NWS La Crosse WI
entry.summary:
The combination of very low relative humidity values, warm temperatures, and dry fuels will result in elevated fire weather conditions this afternoon across southeast Minnesota and southwest into central Wisconsin. Afternoon relative humidity values fall to 15 to 25 percent with winds veering from the west to the northwest through the afternoon. West of the Mississippi River, wind speeds will be 5 to 10 mph with an occasional gust to 15 mph. East of the river, wind speeds will be 10 to 15 mph with gusts up to 20 mph.
Under these conditions, fires will start and spread easily. Please exercise caution with any activities that involve outdoor fires or create sparks, including campfires, grilling, and operating large equipment. Cigarettes should be disposed of and extinguished properly. Please heed any local burn bans.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 11 at 9:04PM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* A weak winter weather system continues to impact the region tonight. This system will bring another round of light snow to the Sierra through Tuesday morning, followed by widespread gusty winds through Tuesday afternoon.
* Additional snowfall through Tuesday will be light with a trace to two inches below 7000 feet and up to six inches along the Sierra crest. Even light snow accumulations can lead to slick roads, so plan extra time for your travels, especially the Tuesday morning commute.
* Wind gusts on Tuesday afternoon will reach 80 to 100 mph along ridges with 30 to 40 mph in Sierra valleys. Lower elevation winds will quickly diminish overnight Tuesday, while Sierra crest winds remain elevated much of this week. Expect bumpy flights and choppy lake waters.
* Drier weather is favored from midweek onward with increasing potential for a strong northeast to east wind event on Thursday into Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Mono; Greater Lake Tahoe Area

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 11 at 7:11PM AKDT until March 12 at 6:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow and blowing snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 8 inches from Anchor Point to Homer and 5 to 10 inches around Seldovia. Northerly winds gusting to 30 mph. Visibility reduced to as low as one half mile at times.
* WHERE...South of Ninilchik, including communities along the Kachemak Bay coast.
* WHEN...From 4 AM to 6 PM AKDT Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult. Blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility to one half mile at times, especially along the Sterling Highway near Anchor Point and for communities along the southern coast of Kachemak Bay.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow will develop over Kachemak Bay early Tuesday morning and remain over the area through at least Tuesday evening. Winds will also increase Tuesday morning, especially along the immediate Cook Inlet coast and across southern Kachemak Bay. The combination of snow and wind could produce areas of blowing snow from Anchor Point and Diamond Ridge south to Seldovia through Tuesday evening. The heaviest snow amounts will likely be around Seldovia. There is still some uncertainty as to when the heaviest snow will taper off. Snow could linger into late Tuesday night, resulting in additional snow accumulations.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Kenai Peninsula

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 11 at 8:35PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Altamaha River At Charlotteville affecting Montgomery, Jeff Davis and Toombs Counties.
Altamaha River At Baxley affecting Wayne, Toombs, Appling and Tattnall Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Tuesday evening at 845 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Altamaha River at Charlotteville.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Bankfull conditions occur along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. Some flooding begins in low lying areas around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage in south Montgomery County. The water will approach portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 13.0 feet, Flood stage is reached. Minor flooding occurs in the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water reaches the top of the public boat ramp by the bridge. Flood waters expand in low lying areas in south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will begin to cover portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 14.0 feet, Minor flooding continues in the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water covers the low portion and entrance of Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge. The public boat ramp is under two feet of water. Flood waters expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be one to two feet deep over portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 16.0 feet, Minor flooding expands into the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water will be one to two feet deep over portions of Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge. Flood waters continue to expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be 2 to 4 feet over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 18.0 feet, Minor flooding expands further into the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. Flood waters will completely cover Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge and begin to flood the slab foundations of the elevated homes. Flood waters expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be 4 to 6 feet deep over large portions of Three Rivers Lane... Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 19.0 feet, Minor flooding expands upstream and downstream from the Highway 221 bridge. Flood waters near 3 feet deep cover Towns Bluff Lane and flood the slab foundations of the elevated homes. Flooding expands further into Montgomery County with the water 5 to 7 feet deep over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. The water reaches the top of boat ramps and parking lots will begin to flood in Towns Bluff Park and along the end of Uvalda Landing Road in Jeff Davis County. At 20.0 feet, Moderate flooding begins. Significant flooding occurs upstream and downstream from the Highway 221 bridge. Flood waters will be near 4 feet deep on Towns Bluff Lane and flood the concrete slab foundations of the elevated homes. Flooding expands further into Montgomery county with the water 6 to 8 feet deep over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. The parking lot at Towns Bluff Park and portions of Uvalda Landing Road will be flooded in Jeff Davis County.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:45 PM EDT Monday the stage was 15.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to 18.1 feet Saturday evening. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Jeff Davis, GA; Montgomery, GA; Toombs, GA

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 11 at 3:45PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Long range computer models are coming into agreement about a moderate to heavy rain event for the middle of the week. The initial surge of moisture will move over the panhandle on Wednesday followed by more moisture Wednesday night and Thursday. Each will bring periods of moderate to heavy precip to the area, with the heaviest rates expected Wednesday night into Thursday. Current 24 hour precipitation totals for the panhandle from Wednesday morning through Thursday morning range from 1 to 2.5 inches, with the highest totals along the outer coast and southern panhandle. By the end of the work week, the plume of moisture directed over more southerly locations will shift northward, bringing another round of moderate to heavy precipitation.
In addition to the heavy precip, another concern is a significantly warmer low level airmass that is projected to move over the panhandle. This warmer air may result in snow levels rising to more than 4000 feet across the southern panhandle and from 2000 to 3500 feet over the northern panhandle by next weekend. Snowmelt at higher elevations will add to the heavy precipitation near sea level that may result in flooding along creeks, streams, and rivers. Ponding in areas with poor or blocked drainage may also become an issue.
We will continue to monitor this potential hazardous situation.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Sitka; Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; City of Hyder; Annette Island

cap:parameter.value: WARMING TEMPERATURES WITH PERIODS OF HEAVY RAIN BEGINNING IN THE MIDDLE OF THIS WEEK

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 11 at 3:45PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary: Cold air in place over the far northern inner channels, Glacier Bay, and the northeast Gulf Coast will be over run by a front with considerable moisture on Wednesday night. Snow from this front is forecast to begin early on Wednesday and increase in intensity through the day. Peak snowfall rates are expected during the night Wednesday night, then diminish rapidly on Thursday morning. Highest snowfall accumulations are expected along the Haines and Klondike highways. There is lower confidence in snow totals for Yakutat due to the possibility of stronger southerly push behind the front raising temperatures high enough to limit accumulation.
entry.cap:areaDesc: City and Borough of Yakutat; Municipality of Skagway; Haines Borough and Klukwan

cap:parameter.value: POTENTIAL FOR HEAVY ACCUMULATING SNOW WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND THURSDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 11 at 3:13PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
Northeast winds of 15 mph gusting to 25 mph over Steese, Elliot and Dalton Highway Summits will continue into tonight. This is causing wind chills of 30 below over Summits. These winds are also causing blowing and drifting snow which will cause snow drifts and could make travel difficult over Summits.
People traveling over summits of the Steese, Elliott and Dalton Highways north of the Chatanika River should be prepared for severe winter conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Dalton Highway Summits; White Mountains and High Terrain South of the Yukon River

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 11 at 11:49AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Bands of moderate to heavy snow showers will continue through Tuesday afternoon along the Seward Highway from Bird Point south to the Hope Cuttoff and Portage Glacier Road through Whittier. Snowfall rates greater than one inch an hour are possible along with visibility reductions of one quarter mile or less at times. Snow accumulations of 12 to 20 inches are possible with the higher totals expected near Portage. Travel conditions may be difficult through these areas.
For the latest road conditions call 511 or visit 511.alaska.gov.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 11 at 11:30AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
After multiple weaker systems move through the area early in the week, long range computer models are coming into agreement about moderate to heavy rain and much warmer temperatures returning to southeast Alaska. These conditions may result in increased runoff that could cause flooding along creeks and rivers as well as ponding in areas with poor or blocked drainage. We will continue to monitor this potential hazardous situation.
The initial surge of moisture will move over the panhandle on Wednesday followed by more moisture Wednesday night and Thursday. Each will bring periods of moderate to heavy precip to the area. Over the latter part of the week, a plume of moisture directed over more southerly locations will shift northward, bringing another round of moderate to heavy precipitation rain rates.
Wednesday into Thursday, 24 hour QPF amounts have a 50 to 90% chance of more than 1 inch of moisture with a lower probability of greater than 2 inches along western slopes. Some of that moisture may start out as snow before switching to rain.
In addition to the heavy precip, another concern is a significantly warmer low level airmass that is projected to move over the panhandle. This warmer air may result in snow levels rising to more than 4000 feet across the southern panhandle and from 2000 to 3500 feet over the northern panhandle by next weekend.
entry.cap:areaDesc: City and Borough of Yakutat; Municipality of Skagway; Haines Borough and Klukwan; Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Sitka; Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; City of Hyder; Annette Island

cap:parameter.value: WARMING TEMPERATURES WITH PERIODS OF HEAVY RAIN BEGINNING IN THE MIDDLE OF THIS WEEK

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 11 at 11:14AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
AFTER A COUPLE WEAKER SYSTEMS PASS BY EARLY IN THE WEEK, LONG RANGE COMPUTER MODELS ARE COMING INTO AGREEMENT ABOUT MODERATE TO HEAVY RAIN AND MUCH WARMER TEMPERATURES RETURNING TO SE AK. THESE CONDITIONS WOULD RESULT IN INCREASED RUNOFF THAT COULD CAUSE FLOODING ALONG CREEKS AND RIVERS AS WELL AS PONDING IN AREAS WITH POOR OR BLOCKED DRAINAGE. WE WILL CONTINUE TO MONITOR THIS POTENTIAL HAZARDOUS SITUATION.
THE INITIAL SURGE OF MOISTURE WILL MOVE INTO THE PANHANDLE ON WEDNESDAY FOLLOWED BY ANOTHER WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND THURSDAY. EACH WILL BRING PERIODS OF MODERATE TO HEAVY PRECIP TO THE AREA. THEN OVER THE LATTER PART OF THE WEEK, A PLUME OF MOISTURE DIRECTED OVER SOUTH LOOKS TO SHIFT NORTHWARD THROUGH THE PANHANDLE, BRINGING ANOTHER ROUND OF INCREASED RAIN RATES.
WEDNESDAY INTO THURSDAY, 24 HOUR QPF AMOUNTS HAVE A 50 TO 90% CHANCE OF MORE THAN 1 INCH OF MOISTURE WITH ISOLATED 20 TO 50% CHANCE OF GREATER THAN 2 INCHES ALONG WESTERN SLOPES. SOME OF THAT MOISTURE MAY START OUT AS SNOW BEFORE SWITCHING TO RAIN.
IN ADDITION TO THE HEAVY PRECIP, ANOTHER CONCERN IS A NOSE OF WARMER AIR THAT IS PROJECTED TO MOVE INTO THE PANHANDLE. THIS NOSE OF WARMER AIR COULD PUSH SNOW LEVELS TO OVER 4000 FEET ACROSS THE SOUTHERN PANHANDLE AND 2000 TO 3500 FEET OVER THE NORTHERN PANHANDLE BY NEXT WEEKEND.
SURFACE TEMPERATURES WILL RESPOND AS WELL. NEXT SATURDAY, COMPUTER MODELS ARE GIVING THE ENTIRE PANHANDLE A 70 TO 100% CHANCE OF SEEING MAX TEMPS GREATER THAN 40 DEGREES. FOR MAX TEMPS GREATER THAN 45 DEGREES, AREAS ALONG AND SOUTH OF FREDERICK SOUND HAVE A GREATER THAN 60% CHANCE WHILE AREAS TO THE NORTH OF FREDERICK SOUND HAVE A 10 TO 40% CHANCE.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 11 at 11:47AM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* Mostly dry conditions prevail through this afternoon ahead of another weak system moving into the region tonight. This system will bring another round of light snow to the Sierra this evening into Tuesday morning, followed by widespread gusty winds through Tuesday afternoon.
* Additional snowfall through Tuesday will be light with a trace to two inches below 7000 feet and up to six inches along the Sierra crest. Even light snow accumulations can lead to slick roads, so plan extra time for your travels, especially the Tuesday morning commute.
* Wind gusts on Tuesday afternoon will reach 80 to 100 mph along ridges with 30 to 40 mph in Sierra valleys. Lower elevation winds will quickly diminish overnight Tuesday, while Sierra crest winds remain elevated much of this week. Expect bumpy flights and choppy lake waters.
* Drier weather is favored from midweek onward with increasing potential for a strong northeast to east wind event on Thursday into Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Mono; Greater Lake Tahoe Area
